title: Northeast B.C. wildfire update — June 2
content: Here's the latest information from the BC Wildfire Service on the Tommy Lakes wildfire, the only wildfire of note in the region.   Tommy Lakes   Location: 29km northeast of Mile 109 Highway 97 (Alaska Highway)    article continues below       Trending Stories       Discovered: Tuesday, May 22, 2018    Size: 22,583 hectares.    Cause: Lightning    Status: Active, 20% contained    Interface: Interface fire    Previous evacuations have been rescinded.    As of 1615 on June 1, 2018, the Peace River Regional District rescinded the Evacuation Alert for Electoral Area B.    Resources:  216 firefighters, 9 helicopters, 20 heavy equipment    Yesterday (June 1), there was no growth on the Tommy Lakes wildfire and the fire did not receive any rain. The cooler temperatures and higher relative humidity continue to aid fire suppression efforts. The crews have made great progress to date and the fire is currently 20% contained.     Today, there are 216 firefighters building and reinforcing guard working to increase containment supported by 9 helicopters along with 20 pieces of heavy equipment.    The primary objectives are to establish machine guard and if conditions permit conduct controlled burning operations, in order to protect oil and gas infrastructure, communities and other values in the vicinity.    On the northwest side of the fire, crews along with heavy equipment are working to secure the guard on the west side of the Beatton River. Crews are also working on a contingency guard along the western flank.    On the southwest flank, crews are establishing hoselay on along the South Nig and mopping-up from the Beatton River to the South Nig road.    On the east flank, crews are working to complete mop-up and patrols along and in the vicinity of the North Nig road. They are also mopping up east of the Beatton Road and continue with direct attack west of the 71km mark on the Beatton Road. Crews are also working to complete mop-up from the North Nig road working south towards the 76km mark on the Beatton Road.    On the northeast flank, crews continue to patrol and mop-up guards constructed off the North Nig and Tommy Lakes roads. They are working to mop-up; east from the 46km mark on the Tommy Lakes road and down the North Nig road, north of the 46km mark on the Tommy Lakes road, and west from the 10km mark on the North Nig road.      In the vicinity of the fire, smoke may be visible to the public.    The Tommy Lakes (G80340) is the result of the amalgamation of the former Beatton Lake (G80340) and the Tommy Lakes Road (G80341). This amalgamation occurred on May 25, 2018.    More information: On May 27, 2018, an Area Restriction Order was put in place for Crown Land in the vicinity of the Tommy Lakes wildfire. This restricts public access to the active wildfire area and access roads within the Tommy Lakes wildfire boundary and surrounding area. For more information regarding the restricted area please refer to the attached order and map.    The public is asked to respect this order to ensure your safety as well as the crews working on the Tommy Lakes wildfire. Public and crew safety is the number one priority of the BC Wildfire Service.     Tommy Lakes fire behaviour in the northwest, June 1, 2018. - BC Wildfire Service
